AvProblem.comment: on extremely steep grass-covered slopes, possible at any time of day

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger is low on steep slopes. Glide-snow avalanches can trigger in all aspects at any time of day or night naturally as long as there is sufficient snow on the ground and grow to medium size, sometimes large size. Avoid zones beneath glide cracks. Apart from gliding snow problem, the greatest danger is from taking a fall.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Due to good nocturnal outgoing radiation and dry air the snowpack was able to dry out and form a melt-freeze crust up to 1800 m, on south-facing slopes up to over 2000 m, which is capable of bearing loads. Firn snow on south-facing slopes during the daytime. On shady slopes, wind-crusts and sometimes still powder. Above 1900 m there are small snowdrifts deposited atop a crust, easily recognized, usually well bonded with the surface, unlikely to trigger. Due to warmth of the ground and moistness of the snowpack, increased glide-snow activity can be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: Star-studded skies on Tuesday night, dry air. On Wednesday, sunny weather, good for backcountry tours, though with some high-altitude cloudbanks passing through (good visibility). Only in the Osterhorn range will there be more cloud cover. Winds light to moderate, in afternoon in high-alpine regions brisk westerly winds in the Northern Alps. At 2000 m: 0 degrees; at 3000 m: -5 degrees.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.

AvProblem.comment: small/thin snowdrift patches, in gullies, steep bowls

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Danger of falling outweighs that of being buried in snow
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger is low. Glide-snow avalanches are a threat up to summit level. Where there is sufficient snow on the ground, large-sized releases are possible, though most are small-to-medium. Avoid zones below glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack layering is favorable by and large. Above 2000 m small snowdrift accumulations are unlikely to trigger. Due to warmth of the ground and moistness of the snowpack, increased glide-snow activity can be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: Star-studded skies on Tuesday night, dry air. On Wednesday, sunny weather, good for backcountry tours, though with some high-altitude cloudbanks passing through (good visibility). Only in the Osterhorn range will there be more cloud cover. Winds light to moderate, in afternoon in high-alpine regions brisk westerly winds in the Northern Alps. At 2000 m: 0 degrees; at 3000 m: -5 degrees.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.

AvProblem.comment: triggerable in few spots in outlying terrain
in extremely steep grass-covered terrain, isolated large avalanches possible, possible at any time of day

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Isolated danger zones in old snowpack
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger is moderate above 2500 m, low below that altitude. In the few danger zones, weak layers in the uppermost part of the snowpack above 2500 m can be triggered by 1 person, esp. in transitions from shallow to deep snow and on steep sunny slopes. In isolated cases the releases can be large-sized. Danger of naturally triggered glide-snow avalanches below 2600 m persists, larger sized avalanches are possible in high altitude starting zones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snow andÂ snowdrifts from last week have settled lie atop faceted layers (from mid-January). Steep sunny slopes have formed a thin melt-freeze crust over this layer which has faceted crystals clinging to it. Where there is a thin crust the faceted crystals are large and constitute a weak layer in the old snow. Beneath the fresh snow and drifts from last week is a faceted layer clinging to a melt-freeze crust (formed in mid-January) near the surface, esp. on E/S/W facing slopes above 2300 m. Firn on south-facing slopes, on shady slopes wind crusts and loose powder can be found. Due to warmth of the ground and moistness of the snowpack, increased glide-snow activity can be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: Star-studded skies on Tuesday night, dry air. On Wednesday, sunny weather, good for backcountry tours, though with some high-altitude cloudbanks passing through (good visibility). Only in the Osterhorn range will there be more cloud cover. Winds light to moderate, in afternoon in high-alpine regions brisk westerly winds in the Northern Alps. At 2000 m: 0 degrees; at 3000 m: -5 degrees.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Isolated danger zones due to gliding snow
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche situation is quite favorable in general. On very steep grass-covered slopes, small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized glide-snow avalanches are possible above 1800 m. Avoid zones below glide cracks. The danger of falling outweighs that of being buried in snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack is generally stable. Due to warmth of the ground and moistness of the snowpack, increased glide-snow activity can be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: Star-studded skies on Tuesday night, dry air. On Wednesday, sunny weather, good for backcountry tours, though with some high-altitude cloudbanks passing through (good visibility). Only in the Osterhorn range will there be more cloud cover. Winds light to moderate, in afternoon in high-alpine regions brisk westerly winds in the Northern Alps. At 2000 m: 0 degrees; at 3000 m: -5 degrees.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.
